bug.short_desc: defaultCssClass of RadioButton is applied to the hidden input

long_desc.thetext: That's useless, since it's hidden. It should be applied to the label which represents the radio button.

It is not useless.
The hidden input field, manages and holds the value of the radio button. The fact that it is hidden is a workaround for a often occurring browser bug, that checkboxes and radiogroups are not completely themeable through CSS.
So we are working with pseudo-elements, and these pseudo-elements react on the state of the checkboxes/radiogroups, when they are hidden/selected/unselected.
Means: This is not a bug.
I understand the workaround and the motivation for it. But why is the css class applied to the hidden element and not to the element which should be styled?

Because the visual elements are css pseudo-elements, which are generated by the CSS, it is not possible to assign classes to these pseudo-elements. In iOS theme for example we do not even use pseudo-elements, and show the native Radio Buttons. So we are very flexible with our themes.
The pseudo-elements always have to be styled according to their no-pseudo-elements.
